texts.definition: The abstract characteristics of diegetic persons.
markups: Many games let players control game elements that represent people or creatures that act in the Game World. When these people or creatures have characteristics not directly shown in the Game World that can change during gameplay, these game elements have an abstract element called Character.

Note: The use of character here is in the meaning of the characteristics of a person rather than the traditional use in art of the representation of a person (Agents is used instead). Also, for this context anything one would be likely to take an intentional stance towards, or perceive that one is intended to take such a stance, is considered a person.

Tabletop roleplaying games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> let each player control their own <style="CurrentLink">Character</style>, and one of the main types of goal in the games is to raise the character's level, stats, or skills. This has been carried over to computer-based version of roleplaying games such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Elder%20Scrolls%20series">The Elder Scrolls series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style>, and games building on the genre, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NetHack">NetHack</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diablo%20series">Diablo series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mass%20Effect%20series">Mass Effect series</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style>.

The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/X-COM%20series">X-COM series</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Jagged%20Alliance%20series">Jagged Alliance series</link></style> lets players control several <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> at once. Typically all these games also players choices in how to improve the <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> during gameplay as rewards for advancing, but several varieties of how they are created exist. Collections of multiple choice questions combined with some point system for skills are common (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Elder%20Scrolls%20series">The Elder Scrolls series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mass%20Effect%20series">Mass Effect series</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style>) while some have one complete point system (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style>). Randomness is often an important component, either for attributes (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NetHack">NetHack</link></style>) or more generally for the characters' backgrounds (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Traveller">Traveller</link></style> and the Lifeboard used in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallen%20Reich">Fallen Reich</link></style>). The tabletop roleplaying games often have multiple systems that the player groups are choose from.

Many action-oriented computer games can be said to have an extremely weak form of the pattern through having just one abstract value, typically a health value. Examples of games that fall in this category include the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%20series">Doom series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%20series">Super Mario series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Legend%20of%20Zelda%20series">The Legend of Zelda series</link></style> (and they typically also have some inventories for weapons or tools). An exception to this can be found in the team-based FPS <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Return%20to%20Castle%20Wolfenstein:%20Enemy%20Territory">Return to Castle Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory</link></style>, where players have <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> that can develop between levels by gaining experience points in various skills.

<style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> are used to add complexity when creating <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> or the <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> controlled by players. The design of <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> in games can either be on the level of creating pre-defined descriptions and presentations of these or by creating rules for how players can create their own <style="Link"><link="player-created-characters">Player-Created Characters</link></style> through the use of patterns such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Avatar%20Personalization">Avatar Personalization</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Initial%20Personalization">Initial Personalization</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Naming">Naming</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="workshopping">Workshopping</link></style> techniques can be used to make possible both modification and full creations of <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> as part of supporting <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Initial%20Personalization">Initial Personalization</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> can exist weakly in games through a couple of design combinations, and these can be used in conjunction with more explicit ways of creating <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style>. Simply having <style="Link"><link="handles">Handles</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style> values in a <style="Link"><link="hud-interfaces">HUD Interface</link></style> (or <style="Link"><link="geospatial-game-widgets">Geospatial Game Widgets</link></style> in the case of <style="Link"><link="handles">Handles</link></style>) does add some abstract qualities to <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="first-person-views">First-Person Views</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="point-interest-indicators">Point of Interest Indicators</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="vision-modes">Vision Modes</link></style> add the abstract characteristics of perceptual functionality to a game which otherwise may only have <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>. However, for more explicit created <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> diegetically important features such as names (often determining the <style="Link"><link="handles">Handle</link></style> that identifies the player's character to other players), gender, and occupations need to be created. Exactly what features are appropriate depend mainly on the type of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alternative%20Realities">Alternative Reality</link></style> gameplay takes place within (e.g. many fantasy <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> games have several different playable races).

<style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> are often given <style="Link"><link="characteristics">Characteristics</link></style> related to the mechanical aspects of the game systems, and these also provide openings for future <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style>. Many different types of <style="Link"><link="characteristics">Characteristics</link></style> are possible: <style="Link"><link="character-levels">Character Levels</link></style> that affect overall power levels and access to various other traits, the numerical <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style> that represent physical or mental characteristics and determine values such as <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style>, and fatigue; the <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Powers">Powers</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style> that affect the likelihood of succeeding with actions and may give <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> such as being a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Producers">Producer</link></style> that can create <style="Link"><link="renewable-resources">Renewable Resources</link></style>; the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Advantages">Advantages</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Disadvantages">Disadvantages</link></style>, quirks, or other ways of describing character traits and motivating initial <style="Link"><link="decreased-abilities">Decreased Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>; the <style="Link"><link="invulnerabilities">Invulnerabilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style>,  and <style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style> that affect threats and opportunities to attack; the <style="Link"><link="inventories">Inventories</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="equipment-slots">Equipment Slots</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="containers">Containers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="pick-ups">Pick-Ups</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="transferable-items">Transferable Items</link></style> which regulate how <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> can have <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>; and the <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> place in social networks within the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> that define their relations with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> (e.g. as as <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> or as having <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Linked%20Destinies">Linked Destinies</link></style>), and the <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> positions in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hierarchical%20Factions">Hierarchical Factions</link></style>, including possible <style="Link"><link="loyalty">Loyalty</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Rivalries</link></style> within those <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="character-alignments">Character Alignments</link></style> can be used as overarching ways of defining what type of person a <style="CurrentLink">Character</style> is - after choosing an alignment the choices regarding <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Powers">Powers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Advantages">Advantages</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Disadvantages">Disadvantages</link></style> can be easier to make. In games with <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, some of these characteristics are usually cosmetic but are still important as this <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Avatar%20Personalization">Avatar Personalization</link></style> supports <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Identification">Identification</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>.

Creating pre-defined <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> lets them fit within <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alternative%20Realities">Alternative Realities</link></style> in a way that can ensure <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> and allows personalized and unique <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> for all <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style>. In games with <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style> goals between players (e.g. fighting games such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tekken%20series">Tekken series</link></style>), pre-created <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> can also be extensively play-tested to ensure <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style>. The use of pre-created <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> is common in games either where <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> regarding gameplay is not a large part of game experience or where <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style>, and any <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style>, is closely tied to a tightly controlled <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structure</link></style>.

Typical ways of letting players create <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> are based on <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="budgeted-action-points">Budgeted Action Points</link></style> (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> illustrate these two approaches, although there are several choices also in the first example). These are in turn used to determine the various characteristics possible mentioned in the previous paragraph. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Initial%20Personalization">Initial Personalization</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> typically provides some level of <style="Link"><link="player-created-characters">Player-Created Characters</link></style>, but this may cause a problem of fitting or adjusting the <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> to have integral role in <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>. This problem can be mitigated by the presence of <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> that can perform the necessary <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style> to make the <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> suitable to the planned events in the game or modify the <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> to fit them. <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> may also emerge from <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> if these are individually given <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> since this means that they become differentiated by their <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>.

It may seem somewhat paradoxical but the answer to the question of who controls the <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> after they have been created does not automatically have to be their creators. That <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> created by the game designers can be either <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> controlled by <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> for players is quite natural, as is the passive use of <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> mainly as a way to provide players with somebody to receive <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> from or to perform <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style> with. But <style="Link"><link="player-created-characters">Player-Created Characters</link></style> do not have to be directly controlled by those players either, the Sims created by players in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sims%20series">Sims series</link></style> are semi-autonomous and can be left completely to their own devices (and if one has created several households the sims from other households are pure <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> for any given game session).

Independent of how the initial <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> are created, the game designer can choose whether <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> should be possible and if players should be able to affect it (including being able to automated it through the use of <style="Link"><link="mules">Mules</link></style>). An alternative way of supporting <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> is through the use of <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style>, which both can be used to provide developmental opportunities during gameplay. <style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style> can in itself create <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style>, but there is a multitude of other patterns that can be used to provide such this pattern when used together with <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style>: <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="character-levels">Character Levels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enforced-agent-behavior">Enforced Agent Behavior</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="loyalty">Loyalty</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sidequests">Sidequests</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="social-dilemmas">Social Dilemmas</link></style>. For <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> during gameplay, if players are able to influence the development or not may mostly depend on if players have been provided in advance by <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Extra-Game%20Information">Extra-Game Information</link></style> or by diegetic <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="red-herrings">Red Herrings</link></style> (which in the latter case make players need to take <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Leaps%20of%20Faith">Leaps of Faith</link></style>).

A critical choice regarding <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> is if the game design should try to make character traits presented diegetically in the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>. Although there may seem to be no obvious reason why to not do so it, the <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> for players may be limited. This not only since <style="CurrentLink">Character</style> presentation is typically done through <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style> (but see <style="Link"><link="environmental-storytelling">Environmental Storytelling</link></style>) which automatically restricts players <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> to perform actions at certain times (and gives <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style>). The presentation done by the design also limits how players can shape the <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> through <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> since it puts restrictions in which direction the <style="CurrentLink">Characters'</style> storyline can develop, at least as long as the players do not wish to break the <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> of the game session.

Many games contain hazards that can <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> or kill <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style>. How deaths should be handled is another design issue that needs to be considered for the pattern. Letting the <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> die is the simplest solution to having <style="Link"><link="death-consequences">Death Consequences</link></style> but may break <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> if important <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> die, and enforce <style="Link"><link="permadeath">Permadeath</link></style> if used on <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style>. Alternatives are using <style="Link"><link="death-consequences">Death Consequences</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="extra-chances">Extra Chances</link></style> (e.g. the fate points in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warhammer%20Fantasy%20Roleplay">Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay</link></style>), <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style> (possibly together with <style="Link"><link="death-consequences">Death Consequences</link></style>), and <style="Link"><link="spawning">Spawning</link></style>. A completely different approach to the death of <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> is to encourage <style="Link"><link="playing-lose">Playing to Lose</link></style>, that is to encourage players to cause bad things to happen to their <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> for the sake of a making a good story.

It should be noted that <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> present in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> may have abstract characteristics and states not part of what constitutes the <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style>. This since technical issues regarding following other objects or routes are neither diegetic objects nor part of what defines a personality.

<style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> handle the abstract qualities of diegetic people and thereby helps maintain <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> since both hiding characteristics that should not be easily detectable but still making them possible to effect the gameplay. Encouraging or enforcing <style="Link"><link="diegetic-communication">Diegetic Communication</link></style> by the <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> is another step that can be takes to maintain <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>; allowing players to use <style="Link"><link="emotes">Emotes</link></style> can promote this type of communication but it is within the players' power to also break the consistency in this case.

<style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> do not have to have pre-made diegetic presentations,  but when they do <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> are the most common form although some games (e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/X-COM%20series">X-COM series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Jagged%20Alliance%20series">Jagged Alliance series</link></style>) make use of <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>. However, the <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> pattern does not need to be combined with any pre-defined ways of presenting people diegetically. Most table-top roleplaying games (such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> and earlier editions of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20and%20Dragons">Dungeons and Dragons</link></style>) support use of <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> in combat situations but make it optional, letting players express their <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> through <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style> using only their own voice and body. Another example of not having a diegetic presence during gameplay can be found in the computer game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alter%20Ego">Alter Ego</link></style>, which keeps track of the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style> for the player's <style="CurrentLink">Character</style> but doesn't present it in the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>. If <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> are complex enough, the presentation <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> provide may need to be augmented by the use of <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style> to provide enough information.

Maintaining <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> for <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> may be easy for those only encountered briefly but <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> and the use of <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destiny</link></style> may be necessary to maintain a longer illusion of personality or intentionality, especially in games striving for <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style>.

Since by definition the information related to <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> is not part of the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, some other way of allowing players to get information about them is needed. This may simply be <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Extra-Game%20Information">Extra-Game Information</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="hud-interfaces">HUD Interfaces</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="geospatial-game-widgets">Geospatial Game Widgets</link></style> presented together with the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> but can also be in the form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Character%20Sheets">Character Sheets</link></style>, the latter typically as a form of <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style> for computer games. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Character%20Sheets">Character Sheets</link></style> may be more or less unavoidable if players need to interact with the <style="CurrentLink">Character</style> statistics, e.g. to increase <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style> when <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Leveling">Leveling</link></style> (as e.g. in games such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls series</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style>).

In <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="budgeted-action-points">Budgeted Action Points</link></style> are quite common solutions to model <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> between <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> and their <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>.

Given that <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>, and especially <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, very often depend on the intentions of fictitious persons, it would seem that <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> are integral to these. This is partly true. The pattern <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> related to the attributes of these persons in relation to the game system and how it affects gameplay.  In this sense <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> strongly affect if and how <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style> emerge from the game structures. This may also be the <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> of the game as <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style> can be used to place specific focus on individual <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style>, and in this case create <style="Link"><link="melodramatic-structures">Melodramatic Structures</link></style>. However, the <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> can exist independently of the gameplay and be told through <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style>. In this case, the main relation between the two patterns is the need to maintain a form of <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> between the <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> gameplay actions and their actions in the narration. In both cases <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> can function as <style="Link"><link="macguffins">MacGuffins</link></style>. A special case of this is games using <style="Link"><link="detective-structures">Detective Structure</link></style> since these require that all information available to a player is tied to one specific <style="CurrentLink">Character</style>.

Players' views on <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> can quite easily be modified through the use of <style="Link"><link="gossip">Gossip</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="contextualization">Contextualization</link></style> also allows players to develop their view of <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> through the use of <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style> that provide context for the "main" narration developing.

<style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> are <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style> representing people and other inhabitants of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> which diegetically have agency. In games with <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> form links between abstract game state values and concrete game state values through their connection to <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>. The <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style> of <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> by players or <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> lead to <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style>, and when doing this well is seen as a goal managing to do so can provide <style="Link"><link="role-fulfillment">Role Fulfillment</link></style> (the possibility of this pattern can further be strengthened by relating <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> to <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> in various ways).. <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> controlled by <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> that are players or <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style> are <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style>, as are <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> who player use for <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style>. When no concrete <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> exists, <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> take the role of <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> in replacement of <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> is one way of creating <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>, although typically needing the use of <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>. When they have <style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> immediately create goals concerning to <style="Link"><link="conceal">Conceal</link></style> these or <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> attempts to exploit them. More generally, threats of <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> that can be avoided by <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> of the <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> give rise to <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> goals.

<style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> provide games with points for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Identification">Identification</link></style> and through these points <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="perspective-taking">Perspective Taking</link></style>, especially in cases where <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> the <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> or <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style> about the <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> is possible. This also makes them a source of <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> in games where the <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> may suffer <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> or other <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>, or where they may die (i.e., being the focus of <style="Link"><link="survive">Survive</link></style> goals). The personalities expressed by <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> make it possible to encourage certain actions and discourages others, and thereby achieving <style="Link"><link="enforced-agent-behavior">Enforced Agent Behavior</link></style> as long as players wish to maintain <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> (<style="Link"><link="enforced-agent-behavior">Enforced Agent Behavior</link></style> can of course be guaranteed for those <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> that are controlled by <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style>). Systems can, at the risk of ruining <style="Link"><link="player-agency">Player Agency</link></style>, enforce such wanted behaviors through the use of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Automated%20Responses">Automated Responses</link></style>.

The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style> <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> can give makes it likely to strengthen the impact of, and widen the range of, <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> usable in the game, especially in the case of <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style> or when <style="Link"><link="player-planned-development">Player-Planned Development</link></style> of their <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> exists. The presence of <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> also allows more detailed <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> and richer <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> where social relationships can be important components.

The variety of values associated with <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> open up for a range of <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style> through raised <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>, such as <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="decreased-abilities">Decreased Abilities</link></style> through received <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style>, that can occur during gameplay. Gaining <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> can also work as <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>. When these types of <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> allow players some form of control over the <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style>, this leads to increased <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> in games as well as creates <style="Link"><link="player-planned-development">Player-Planned Development</link></style>, which is a form of <style="Link"><link="investments">Investment</link></style> and allows the development of <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style>. This is also a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Customizable%20Development">Customizable Development</link></style>, which can allow a game system to acknowledge <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player%20Time%20Investments">Player Time Investments</link></style> and can support <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style> to the <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style>. These attachments do likely need <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style> since they can require many hours play over several play sessions to arise. The possibility of <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> or equipping <style="Link"><link="armor">Armor</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style> make <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> able to instantiate <style="Link"><link="player-character-skill-composites">Player/Character Skill Composites</link></style> as long as some player skill component exists in the actions performed. It should be noted that simply <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> can also provide <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> and this can catch all diegetic aspects of <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> that specific rules otherwise would miss.

When differences between <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> exist before gameplay begins, this leads to <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-starting-conditions">Asymmetric Starting Conditions</link></style>. If these are not equally powerful this can disrupt <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> but can also be seen as a way of providing <style="Link"><link="difficulty-levels">Difficulty Levels</link></style>. In <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, having <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> in <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> where they have different <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> allows <style="Link"><link="orthogonal-differentiation">Orthogonal Differentiation</link></style> and lets players perform <style="Link"><link="team-combos">Team Combos</link></style>. This also allows players to specialize in different <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style> regardless if <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> exists or not, and gives opportunities of engaging in <style="Link"><link="team-strategy-identification">Team Strategy Identification</link></style>. One specific case, used in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hattrick">Hattrick</link></style>, is to have <style="Link"><link="coaches">Coaches</link></style> as <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> also. However, the differences in abilities may cause <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> to be disrupted. Games with <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> of <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> where <style="Link"><link="team-elimination">Team Elimination</link></style> is possible can motivate <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style> as a consequence of such elimination. Use of <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> as members of <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> also raises the question of allowing <style="Link"><link="reserves">Reserves</link></style> to have a possibility of choosing which <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> to make use of in particular gameplay situations.

For games using <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Character%20Sheets">Character Sheets</link></style>, the <style="CurrentLink">Character</style> information can be a type of <style="Link"><link="gameplay-statistics">Gameplay Statistics</link></style> and this is more or less unavoidable in tabletop <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> games. This can of course also occur whenever any information contained within <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style> are stored so they can be accessed outside play sessions.

For <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Online%20Games">Online Games</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style> where players log onto the games to control <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style>, these can become <style="Link"><link="purchasable-game-advantages">Purchasable Game Advantages</link></style> since players can sell each other the access to them.

Depending on the amount of information stored about <style="CurrentLink">Characters</style>, and how much updating players need to do, the pattern can give rise to <style="Link"><link="excise">Excise</link></style>.
